choices.text: Decreased levels of thyroid binding globulin
Increased levels of thyroid binding globulin
Subclinical hypothyroidism
Increased progesterone

questions.text: A 23yr primigravida is seen in the OPD at 10 weeks. An intern orders her thyroid profile. Her TSH is normal and total T3 and T4 levels which are found to be increased. What could be the possible reason for increased total T3 and T4?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Increased levels of thyroid binding globulin

  • Estrogen increases the synthesis of thyroid binding globulin
  • Hence the total levels of T4 and T3 are increased in pregnancy.
  • Values of Free T4 and Free T3 are unaltered and so are more accurate in pregnancy

Ref: Page no 1118, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Renal clearance of iodine is increased due to an increased GFR
There is an inhibitory effect of hCG on the thyroid gland in the 1st trimester
The serum protein bound iodine is increased in pregnancy
Thyroxine binding globulin increases and reaches a plateau by 20 weeks

questions.text: All Are true regarding thyroid physiology in pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. There is an inhibitory effect of hCG on the thyroid gland in the 1st trimester

Thyroid Physiology in Pregnancy

  • The α-subunits of hCG and TSH are similar and hence hCG has intrinsic thyrotropic activity (stimulatory effect on the thyroid gland)
  • Pregnancy is associated with an increased iodine requirement (50%); maternal serum iodine levels fall due to increased GFR and increased renal clearance of iodine.
  • Thyroid Binding Globulin rises in pregnancy; peaks at 20 weeks; hence
  • Increased total T4 levels (starts 6 – 9 weeks; plateaus at 18 weeks)
  • Increased Total T3 levels
  • Free T3 and T4 –unchanged
  • Increase mean thyroid volume (12 to 15 ml); starts at 14 – 16 weeks; regresses postpartum
  • Fetus: relies on maternal T4; starts its own production at 10 – 12 weeks

 

Ref: Page no 57, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: 6 weeks
12 weeks
20 weeks
28 weeks

questions.text: Fetal thyroid starts functioning at:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 12 Weeks

  • The fetal thyroid starts functioning at 12 weeks
  • Till then, the fetus is entirely dependent on the maternal supply of T4 through the placenta, for all neurologic development.

Ref: Page no 57, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: Total T4
Thyroid binding globulin
Protein bound iodine
TSH

questions.text: All are increased in pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. TSH

 

Ref: Page no 57, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: 100 µg/L
150 µg/L
250 µg/L
500 µg/L

questions.text: The recommended daily allowance of iodine in pregnancy (as per the WHO) is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 250µg/L

  • Iodine requirement is increased in pregnancy
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) has recently revised the Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) for iodine in pregnancy from 200 to 250 μg/L. 

Ref:https://www.fogsi.org/wp-content/uploads/gcpr/GCPR-on-Thyroid-Guideline-2019.pdf

choices.text: 1st and 2nd trimester: 2.5mIU/L; 3rd trimester: 3mIU/L
1st trimester: 2.5mIU/L; 2nd and 3rd trimester: 3mIU/L
1st and 3rd trimester: 3mIU/L; 2nd trimester: 2.5mIU/L
1st trimester: 3mIU/L; 2nd and 3rd trimester: 2.5mIU/L

questions.text: A 24-year woman was screened for hypothyroidism for 6 weeks. What are the trimester specific cut offs for TSH in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1st trimester: 2.5mIU/L; 2nd and 3rd trimester: 3mIU/L

  • It is recommended that all pregnant women should be screened at 1st antenatal visit by measuring TSH levels. TSH cut off should be lower rather than keeping it on 4.0 mIU/L. However, the trimester specific TSH cut off recommended are:
  • 1st trimester 2.5 mIU/L
  • 2nd trimester, 3.0 mIU/L
  • 3rd trimester, 3.0 mIU/L

Ref-https://www.fogsi.org/wp-content/uploads/gcpr/GCPR-on-Thyroid-Guideline-2019.pdf

choices.text: Within 24 h of birth
After 14 days
Between the 2nd – 4th day
Screening only if the baby is lethargic

questions.text: A 36 y Primigravida who is known to be hypothyroid and is on treatment delivers a 3.5Kg male baby. She is worried about the effect of her hypothyroidism on the baby. When should the neonate be screened?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Between 2nd- 4th day

  • Screening of all infants should be performed between two and four days of birth.
  •  If this is not possible, testing should be performed before discharge or within seven days of birth

 

Ref: https://www.aafp.org/afp/2007/0801/p439.html

choices.text: The initial phase is usually a destruction induced thyrotoxicosis
The incidence is higher in diabetic women
It includes postpartum thyroid dysfunction with an onset within 1 months of delivery
20-30% of women will develop permanent hypothyroidism by 6-7 years

questions.text: All are true regarding postpartum thyroiditis except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It includes postpartum thyroid dysfunction with an onset within 1 months of delivery

 

Postpartum thyroiditis:

  • Transient autoimmune thyroiditis – found in 5-10% of women
  • Defined as postpartum thyroid dysfunction with an onset within 12 months of delivery and can include hyperthyroidism, hypothyroidism or both
  • Upto 50% of women with anti-thyroid Abs in the 1st trimester will develop
  • Women with type 1 Diabetes – increased risk
  • Typically, 2 phases
  1. Destruction induced thyrotoxicosis
    1. Abrupt onset
    2. Small goiter palpable
    3. Fatigue, palpitations – common symptoms
    4. Lasts for a few months
    5. Treated with beta blockers
  2. Hypothyroidism
    1. 4 - 8 months postpartum
    2. Thyroxine replacement for 6-12 months
  • 20-30% risk of developing permanent hypothyroidism; up to 50% risk if TPO antibodies are present

choices.text: I131 therapy
Methimazole
Propylthiouracil
Thyroid surgery

questions.text: Which of the following is absolutely contra-indicated in pregnancy for the management of thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. I131 therapy

Explanation:

  • Thyroid ablation with therapeutic radioactive iodine is contra-indicated in pregnancy
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy can be performed after thyrotoxicosis is medically controlled; surgery is best accomplished in the 2nd trimester
  • Medical treatment with Propylthiouracil and Methimazole can be given even though there is slightly higher risk of anomalies with Methimazole

 

Ref: Page no 1120, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Lamotrigine
Levetiracetam
Valproate
Gabapentin

questions.text: Which of the following antiepileptic drugs is most associated with teratogenicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Valproate

 

Explanation:

 

  • Valproate is strongly associated with teratogenicity and is generally avoided during pregnancy unless absolutely necessary. The defects can include neural tube defects, craniofacial defects, cardiovascular malformations, and limb defects. Due to these risks, valproate is generally avoided in women of childbearing age and during pregnancy unless there are no suitable alternatives.

 

Other options:

 

  • Lamotrigine is generally considered one of the safer antiepileptic drugs during pregnancy. While there is some risk of teratogenicity with any antiepileptic drug, the risk with lamotrigine is relatively low compared to others, particularly valproate.
  • Like lamotrigine, levetiracetam is also considered to be relatively safe in pregnancy.
  • Gabapentin is less commonly associated with teratogenicity than valproate, but it is not considered as safe as lamotrigine or levetiracetam. Gabapentin may be used in pregnancy when the benefits outweigh the risks, but it is not the first choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pregnancy and Epilepsy

 

  • There is an increased risk of major congenital malformations due to Anti-epileptic Drugs (AEDs). However certain AEDS like lamotrigine, levetiracetam and carbamazepine are commonly used and considered the safest agents. Poly-therapy increases the risk of malformations.
  • Sodium valproate infers the highest risk of congenital malformations (especially Neural tube defects).
  • Increased risk of Fetal growth restriction in women on AEDs.
  • There is an increased risk of developing childhood epilepsy in the fetus.
  • Folic acid (5mg) should be taken pre conceptionally and throughout pregnancy to reduce the risk of congenital malformations and long-term cognitive effects
  • Aim for monotherapy with the longest effective AED dose if possible. If taking sodium valproate, this needs to be changed to an alternative AED prior to conception.

 

Ref : Williams Textbook of obstetrics 25th edition pg 1160

choices.text: Immediate cesarean delivery
Administration of intravenous benzodiazepines
Maintenance of left lateral decubitus position and airway management
Immediate discontinuation of antiepileptic drugs

questions.text: What is the initial recommended management for a pregnant woman with epilepsy who has a seizure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Maintenance of left lateral decubitus position and airway management

 

Explanation:

 

  • If a pregnant woman with epilepsy has a seizure, the priority is to prevent injury and maintain oxygenation. Placing her in the left lateral decubitus position helps maintain uterine perfusion and prevent supine hypotension, while ensuring airway management is crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Immediate cesarean delivery (Option A) is not indicated unless there are obstetric reasons
  • Intravenous benzodiazepines (Option B) might be used for status epilepticus but are not the first step.
  • Immediate discontinuation of antiepileptic drugs (Option D) is not recommended as it can increase the risk of further seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of a seizure attack during pregnancy/ in labor

 

  • Left lateral tilt (or manual displacement of the uterus)
  • Oxygenation
  • Benzodiazepines (IV lorazepam 2-4 mg bolus repeated every 10-20 mins or IV diazepam 5-10 mg in slow bolus if lorazepam is unavailable)
  • Continuous electronic fetal heart rate monitoring.
  • In refractory cases IV phenytoin can be used: Loading dose of 18mg/ Kg; increased to 5 mg/ Kg to a maximum rate of 50 mg/ minute.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of obstetrics 25th edition pg 734
